title: Ticket #1309: DAGMan: retry subset of a DAG
description:
Goal: the ability to have a DAG node fail, and in doing so cause previously successful nodes to be considered to fail, including possibly RETRYing.

Take this simple DAG consisting of many separate chains of jobs. (This is based on the "Use case" described in #1308, but this example should be self-contained.) 

JOB tar_1 tar_1.sub
JOB scp_1 scp_1.sub
JOB validate_1 validate_1.sub
PARENT tar_1 CHILD scp_1
PARENT scp_1 CHILD validate_1

JOB tar_2 tar_2.sub
JOB scp_2 scp_2.sub
JOB validate_2 validate_2.sub
PARENT tar_2 CHILD scp_2
PARENT scp_2 CHILD validate_2

CATEGORY tar_1 TAR
CATEGORY tar_2 TAR
MAXJOBS TAR 2
CATEGORY scp_1 SCP
CATEGORY scp_2 SCP
MAXJOBS SCP 2
CATEGORY validate_1 VALIDATE
CATEGORY validate_2 VALIDATE
MAXJOBS VALIDATE 2

There are only two chains listed above, but picture them going up to say tar_100, scp_100, validate_100.

The complication is that if any step fails, I want to try again, going all of the way back to the TAR step. This is not currently possible with DAGMan. The most obvious option is nested DAGs, one per chain. DAGMan will helpfully try to continue using the rescue sub-DAG, but that's easy to override by using a POST script to reset the sub-DAG. The more serious problem is that using sub-DAGs, the CATEGORYs are no longer respected.

One possibility is to press something like categories into service: 

LINKFAILURE tar_1 scp_1 validate_1 RETRY 5
LINKFAILURE tar_2 scp_2 validate_2 RETRY 5

However, that lets you cherry pick random nodes, which might be problematic if they're disconnected. Another possibility is to use DAG splicing, and to retry the entire splice. This ensures that all of the nodes are connected with a clear "single" entry point and exit point. This might look like:

D1.dag: 

JOB tar tar_1.sub
JOB scp scp_1.sub
JOB validate validate_1.sub
PARENT tar CHILD scp
PARENT scp CHILD validate
CATEGORY tar TAR
CATEGORY scp SCP
CATEGORY validate VALIDATE

D2.dag: 

JOB tar tar_2.sub
JOB scp scp_2.sub
JOB validate validate_2.sub
PARENT tar CHILD scp
PARENT scp CHILD validate
CATEGORY tar TAR
CATEGORY scp SCP
CATEGORY validate VALIDATE

Top level DAG: 

SPLICE D1 D1.dag RETRY 5
SPLICE D2 D2.dag RETRY 5
MAXJOBS TAR 2
MAXJOBS SCP 2
MAXJOBS VALIDATE 2

This was a real problem encountered, see the "Use case" described in #1308 for more information. However, it turns out that that use case is even more complicated, and this addition wouldn't be enough. It may be that any problem that needs such functionality might also require other problematic functionality, which might be an argument against implementing this. #1308 offers a more general solution at the cost of much more work for the end user.

2014-Mar-19 15:47:17 by wenger:
I just talked to Karan from the Pegasus team, and a special case of this is a fairly high priority for them: they want the capability for a node failure to force a retry of the failed node's immediate parent; furthermore, that parent would only have a single child.

(The use case for Pegasus is that they want to move the planning function from the PRE script of a sub-DAG to a separate node, for the sake of throttling. But if the sub-DAG fails they want to re-do the planning as well as the actual sub-DAG.)

So one thing I need to think about is this: if we implement some kind of multi-node retry, is it worth just implementing the immediate parent retry, or is it worth implementing a general capability of "backing up" through any linear subset of the DAG? In other words, is the "immediate parent retry" significantly simpler to implement?

Also, for a semi-general case of this, one of the things I was wondering about was how to specify the subset of the DAG to be retried. But if we only allow retrying linear sections of the DAG, we could just specify the node name at which to start the retry in the retry command.

Hmm -- I was just thinking that the really tricky aspect of this might be getting it to work with recovery mode...

2014-Mar-20 11:27:06 by wenger:
Maybe we could have a syntax like this: 

  RETRY <JobName> <NumberOfRetries> [UNLESS-EXIT <value>] [JOB <retry job>]

where <retry job> would be the job we would start the retry at. (So the current single-node retry implementation would be the same as having <retr job> == <JobName>.

2014-Apr-28 09:19:58 by wenger:
I just talked to Brian Bockelman about this at Condor Week. He'd really like to see this, because it would solve a problem he has with POST scripts. (If we implement a simple case of more flexible retry it would essentially allow one job to act as the POST script for another job.)

So if we implement this, #1111 and #186 are probably lower-priority.
